title: How to write a good resume if I'm still a student without any work experience - Quora

response.answer_text: You have pages of job experience; you just aren't thinking of it in that way. Instead of job experience use the term experience doing a job, and you will see lots of experience appear. Whenever you helped clean anything, you were gaining such experence. When ever you watched a younger person, cared for a pet, visited your grandparents, or did anything at your church, you were gaining experience at a job. Did you ever volunteer to do anything? Help at the snack bar, or be a runner at a debate contest, or visit school on a vacation day to help a teacher? Ever helped your dad do household repairs or work on the car? All of these things are experience doing a job — job experience. Every year we had to remind students that when reporting service for Honor Society, chores around the house and any help they gave to others were, indeed, service — job experiences. Don't sell yourself short. Are you a scout? Ever set up camp — experience. Band? Ever help set up a trip or the band room? Experience. Ever help cleanup after a dance or decorate for an activity? Job experience. Ever done any stage craft — helped run lights or paint backdrops or care for costumes? Job experience. Ever help collect for a charity? Job experience. Here's a big one. Ever been a TA, a teacher's aide? Ever help tutor your brothers or sisters or friends? That is teaching experience. Ever helped out at a civic event? A city parade or a fireworks show or a concert? Ushered there or passed out programs or helped set up or take down chairs? Job experience. Sit down and think back. You must have given help thousands of times during your life. All of these times are job experiences.

Two things you can do. Write a better one than most people. Most people just make unsupported claims “I am good at…” “I am familiar with… software” “I am dedicated/hardworking/ambitious/etc.) Don’t claim it - demonstrate it. What have you done that shows that attribute? If you cannot give much then use words like interested or like. Compare “I am good at math” with “I really like math”. A potential employer usually reacts well to someone who is interested in a work topic, and likes the kind of things you will have to do.Get the experience you can use to develop and demonstrate the attributes. Become a committee member of a student society - best of all, an officer at some point. Stand as class rep. Volunteer for charity: part-time in a charity shop, or collecting; help out in an old people’s home, or soup kitchen. Organize a sports event. Get a group of students to do something interesting. Think about how you can use the experience. Did you work with people? Sometimes difficult ones? Were you trusted with money or some important organizational task? Did you have any actual responsibility? What did you learn? “This helped me to understand…” Did you deal with any difficult situations? (You can even learn from failures.)

Don’t worry about it too much. The people that are going to hire you know that you don’t have any experience. They are hiring someone right out of college to do something that doesn’t require experience. Ignore the 2+ years experience requirement for entry level jobs. Apply anyway. What you should focus on is extra-curricular activity, networking, skills that match the job description. Also, a good cover letter and objective statement that matches the job description is a must for anyone right out of college applying to jobs for which there is any degree of competition. Connect with the people that you might be working with on Linkedin. Let them know you are interested in this position that was just posted and ask if they know anyone you can speak with. Larger company’s HR departments don’t like to be worked around, but let’s face it, if you are competing with people that are just like you for a job then you need to find some advantage.

How can I write a good resume if I'm still a student without any work experience? For your first job, you will be hired for your academic performance and the potential you demonstrate. Early indications of high potential are leadership roles in any organizations in which you’re involved, school projects that demonstrate proficiency in one ore more skills, or academic achievement. If you are also working part-time to help fund your education, you should list it, particularly if there are achievements relating to being reliable—most employers tend to think students are irresponsible.

response.answer_text: Resumes should describe a candidate’s competencies, industry knowledge, and work history. In case that there are no enough details for the work history, you can just highlight your education and hands-on learning from recent degree or certifications taken. For the recruiters, it is essential to know that potential employees have the knowledge and skills which can be applied at work. There are plenty of samples or formats to be used for students who are seeking employment while still at school.

Base your resume around your achievements. This could be your school work that showcases your talents, like honors programs, high GPA, clubs, sports, or anything that you have been recognized for. Before you do your resume my suggestion would be to google resumes and see what some different styles are and common content. When you are seeking a job the resume is often used to decide who to interview or not, so it is really important you put a lot of effort into making sure it reflects your skills. Best of luck, Jim

Think of work skills you have demonstrated while serving on a school event committee or similar. For example, as treasurer of the Ecology Club, I created a budget and accounting system. I received in $700 in donations, acknowledged the donors with thank you emails, and paid out $600 in expenses for our community garden project.

I had Nine jobs (maybe more) from junior year of high school until I finished my graduate degrees and was seeking full time employment. Get some JOBS during the school year and during the summers. Easy.

Look at your extracurricular activities. Did you hold a leadership positions? If you're not in extracurricular activities, join some. Start working a part time job and work towards getting a leadership position. Good luck
